THE SCHOOL ADMINISTRATOR
September 1957
Plans Shaping Up for Regional Drive-In
Conferences at Spokane and Allentown
In the works are program plans designed
to help community school administrators in
two widely separated regions. These admin¬
istrators will meet at Spokane, Washington,
and Allentown, Pennsylvania, this fall in
regional drive-in conferences sponsored by
A AS A, the NEA Department of Rural Edu¬
cation, and the Council of Chief State School
Officers. Other professional organizations,
agencies, and institutions in each region are
cooperating.
Northwest Conference
In the Northwest Regional Drive-In Con¬
ference on Community School Administra¬
tion, which will meet in Spokane, Novem¬
ber 17, 18, and 19, superintendents from
Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington
will be looking for hints and helps to make
teaching better. Carl Jensen, superintend¬
ent of H i g h 1 i n e
School District, Se¬
attle, Washington,
as general chairman
of the conference, is
shaping up the pro¬
gram details. He has
this to say about the
Spokane conference:
“Talk to almost
any administrator in
the Northwest re¬
gion about his work,
and nine times out
of ten he will tell
you he believes that leadership in improv¬
ing instruction is his most important re¬
sponsibility. Yet despite this belief he is
more likely than not to tell you that he is
not meeting this responsibility nearly as
well as he ought to meet it.
“Planning, constructing, and equipping
school buildings, developing and adminis¬
tering the school budget, employing a school
staff, keeping the public informed about
what the schools are doing, and the hundred
and one other jobs that must be done to set
up the school organization and keep it under
way, keep the superintendent’s nose so close
to the grindstone that he has little or no
energy left to devote to the all-important
job of instructional improvement.”
“In this conference,” Superintendent Jen¬
sen says, “we are trying to learn how to
get out of this dilemma.”
C. C. Trillingham, AASA president¬
elect, fresh from two years’ experience as
chairman of the AASA commission for the
1957 yearbook, The Superintendent as In¬
structional Leader, will keynote the confer¬
ence. Dean Zeno B. Katterle’s general ses¬
sion address on “The Inservice Education of
School Administrators” will be another high¬
light.
In smaller discussion group meetings and
through special reports of actual experience,
these school administrators will get down to
such practical problems as taking stock of
actual educational needs, developing com¬
munity readiness for improving instruction,
using research findings to make teaching
better, the job of the principal as an in¬
structional leader, and effective staff com¬
munication.
Conference at Allentown
There is another brand new drive-in con¬
ference in the making. Superintendents from
Pennsylvania, Ohio, and New York will
meet, November 14, 15, and 16, at Allen¬
town, Pennsylvania, in the first drive-in
conference in this middle-states region.
Now that this conference is a reality, or
almost a reality, it must have a name, and
what to name it has become a perplexing
problem. There has been no lack of sug¬
gestions. Seems like everybody wants to
help. Just to mention a few of the helpful
hints—the Lake Erie Conference, since all
three states border on Lake Erie; the Middle
States Conference, since these three states
are midway between something or other;
the Tri-State Conference, mainly because
that was an easy name to think up; and the
PONY Conference, which is one of the first
of the alphabetic discoveries, so common¬
place in recent years, we have seen that
makes sense.
Anyway, there is a new drive-in confer¬
ence coming soon with a bang-up program
under the leadership of Superintendent
John S. Cartwright of Allentown, Penn¬
sylvania, chairman; John H. Moehle, su¬
perintendent of Onteora Central School,
Boiceville, New York; and W. E. Weagly,

county superintendent of schools, Sandusky,
Ohio. Attention will be focused on such prob¬
lems as school building needs, school legis¬
lation, personnel practices, and school pub¬
lic relations.
Among the high¬
lights of this con¬
ference will be gen¬
eral session ad¬
dresses by Professor
Norton Beach, of
Teachers College,
Columbia Univer¬
sity; Lewis Harris,
executive secretary
of the Ohio School
Boards Association;
R. Merle Eyman,
John Cartwright assistant state su¬
perintendent, Colum¬
bus, Ohio; and Mayor Donald V. Hock of
Allentown.
In a series of special reports, superin¬
tendents in this region will share their ac¬
tual experiences with movable school build¬
ings, financing building programs through
state authority, buildings without corridors,
municipal: annexation for school government
purposes, recruitment practices, and orienta¬
tion programs for new teachers.
